[b]Nobody wants[/b] to admit it, but the games we like the most have a good amount of 'bullshit' in them.
This one encourages you to grab the inch and take it a mile- punishing you harshly for not doing so. [b]But the same randomness[/b] that accelerates one decision into an FPS-melting speedrun, stops you from getting comfortable, it stops you from taking a character and only playing them until the very end, it stops you from using one strategy, one item, over and over and over. [b]There's always a challenge,[/b] and that very idea alone will keep you hooked, even after the hundreds of hours of unlocking everything.
And instead of using this ultimate power to exploit you for microtransactions or ad time, it just uses it to keep you having fun. I can't believe that's a positive of modern games.

[b]Random mechanics[/b] and a strong grind are some of my most despised things, but through over 10 years of love, this game has never disrespected me in a way that's commonplace for most releases nowadays. I play it when I want to play it, for how long I want to play it for. I've played since release and I'll probably keep playing for many many years into the future.

[b]God I wish[/b] more games were like Isaac. 
Lua is a fantastic language, and I recommend anyone who likes really ambitious mechanics to give it a try for their next game project.

[b]It's a 10/10.[/b] I recommend [b]everyone[/b] give it a try.

For somewhat of a different review, I've had a lot of friends who keep trying to get into games and really struggle due to not playing games as a kid and being unfamiliar with controlling a character. Games that I see as easy are frustrating and hard, and games with easy controls to me are very difficult to someone who has never used a keyboard/controller for a character before. I used to tell people NOT to play the binding of isaac as one of their first games because it IS A HARD GAME, however despite my warnings I have seen many friends try this game for one reason or another and then get unexpectedly into it. Playing for many days/weeks/months, learning how to control a character well, and getting far into it. I was initially pretty confused as to why a game like this was so consistently popular among my friends who weren't very experienced with games, but I think a big reason for it is because the pushback from the game, the difficulty, the progression, and the general gameplay loop is so naturally integrated and adapts to YOU so extremely well that it becomes enjoyable for mostly everyone. The progression is wonderful, even after playing the game on-and-off for years. Incredible game in base and the DLC (particularly repentance) has made this one of my favorite and most played games. Would recommend, especially on a sale!

But seriously, this game saved my life. I was very very depressed a few years ago and played this game pretty much 10 hours a day and slept the rest. Infinite replayability, one full run usually last between 30 to 45 minutes (if you don't die) so it's easy to play for a bit before going to work, school, etc. With the various DLC, there's a lot of options and alternate routes you can take which spices things up, and the 637 achievements (with DLC) gives personal objectives for each run if you find yourself getting bored through playing passively. 

A lot of items almost necessitate having the wiki open to understand how they work if you aren't familiar with them, although this is mainly just if you want to minmax the game or be efficient and make the best decisions for surviving your run.

WARNING: SOME SPOILERS!!!

The early game is a lot of fun. The RNG can be awesome or brutal, and that's part of the fun. The items can have some cool synergies, or even game breaking combos (which is also part of the fun). Those aspects are very addictive and more importantly, enjoyable. However, the later levels (Womb, Cathedral, Chest) are really boring, both visually and game-play-wise. They are poorly thought out padding, and inexcusably lazy design. The choices the designers made for those levels are baffling. Also, avoid the Repentance DLC. This sounds like I'm not recommending the game, but it really is worthwhile, just be prepared to be underwhelmed when you unlock later levels. Great game but flawed.

Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself - drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was, until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above. "Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved." "I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. Again, the voice called to her. "Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins." "I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in Thee," Isaac's mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world. One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her. "You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to Me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you." "Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged. "To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life, as an offering to Me to prove you love Me above all else." "Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement, hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

You know, when I started playing this game for the first time, I thought it was going to be what so many of the nay-saying reviews claimed that it would be. I expected some wannabe-edgy "Reddit Atheist" style bashing of the Christian faith. I expected no nuance, no emotion other than anger from this game.

I came out with tears in my eyes.

SPOILERS AHEAD:

[spoiler]
This game explores the effect of religious zealotry on children. I would compare it to Stephen King's "Carrie" in a way, with Isaac having a wildly religious and abusive mother and an absent father. His mother is obsessed with an idea of spiritual redemption, presumably as a means to compensate for the father's abandonment and theft from the family. Isaac is deeply affected by this, and he comes to the conclusion that his parents' separation is his fault, believing himself to be sinful because of his mother's harsh words. He then (presumably) ends his life by suffocating in a chest, leaving his mother to grieve over his dead body.

What this game does brilliantly is making you question if anything in the story is real. You gain bits of information about the game through the endings- the final of which implies that either Isaac is coping with his demise as he ascends to heaven, or that it was all merely a story told to Isaac's father by Isaac, with his parents still in a happy relationship. There are references to Isaac's journey into Purgatory, but you still can't tell how much of it is real. You can't even tell if Isaac's mother even tried to kill him in the first place, potentially suggesting that he's using that to justify his suicide. Everything is simultaneously murky and clear. This game is a genius example of how to use an unreliable narrator while still providing a functional, dark narrative.  [/spoiler]

Why I praise this game so much is that it made me reflect on myself and my religion. This game takes many cues from Catholicism, my personal faith. It made me look at the dogmatism in my own life, in my church, and in the greater institution as a whole. I wept at the final ending, especially given how I lost my father at a fairly young age. All of this pain and despair I felt led me to think of this as one of my favorite games of all time.

Bravo, Edmund.

I never expected to play this as much as I have, however I regret nothing. This game exceeded my expectations for both difficulty and replayability. It has a very difficult learning curve before you really get the hang of it. Stick with it and you will really get to enjoy the game at its fullest. The DLC is great at making the game harder and longer. I will never 100% this game and I am ok with that. Any achievement that I earn now really feels like it truly is an achievement. Highly recommend. Buy this game.

"The Binding of Isaac" is an incredibly captivating and endlessly enjoyable video game. With its procedural generated levels, each playthrough offers a unique and unpredictable experience, making it feel like an infinite adventure. The game's mix of roguelike elements, challenging gameplay, and a darkly imaginative storyline creates an addictive loop that keeps players coming back for more. Its variety of items, power-ups, and different character abilities ensure that no two runs are ever the same, guaranteeing an endless amount of fun and excitement for gamers looking for a game that constantly surprises and delights.

The Binding of Isaac is a highly acclaimed game that offers a unique and challenging experience. Here are some key points from various reviews:

IGN describes the game as having "creepy-cute dungeons" that are different and challenging every time you play.
According to a review on Reddit, the game is pick-up-and-play, rewards repeated playthroughs, and has a very unique aesthetic. It is also known for being tough-but-fair.
Metacritic praises The Binding of Isaac, stating that it successfully achieves everything it sets out to do. The story is interesting, the gameplay is fantastic, and the art and music are wonderful.
However, a negative review on Reddit mentions that the game can be a bit tedious, especially with the backtracking required after clearing out a floor.

Overall, The Binding of Isaac has received positive reviews for its gameplay, aesthetics, and challenging nature. It offers a unique and engaging experience for players who enjoy dungeon-crawling and roguelike games.

Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself - drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was, until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above. "Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved." "I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. Again, the voice called to her. "Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins." "I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in Thee," Isaac's mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world. One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her. "You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to Me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you." "Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged. "To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life, as an offering to Me to prove you love Me above all else." "Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement, hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

In a pixelrealm, where sprites twixtly swirl,
Doth lie The Binding of Isaac, a curios' hurl.
There Isaac, with tearful arms and might,
Doth delve dungeons deep, in cyclical flight.

The art, a jumble of whimsy's array,
Rooms, puzzles spun in a quirky play.
Monstrosities, bosses, a Seussical scene,
Like figments dreamt, in hues that careen!

Power-ups, each a fantastique delight,
In this realm amorphous, a curious sight.
A saga unfolds, in each quest anew,
The Binding of Isaac, whimsy's debut!

In The Binding of Isaac: Rebirt, you play as Gruff McGrufferson, the gruffest, toughest dude around. But under that gruff exterior, he is actually a wobbling mound of jelly. Our pal Gruff the jelly man must wobble his way around the basement and a demonic womb, fighting a bunch of angry demons and their sickly looking pals.

Unfortunately for our chum Gruff McJellyman, his wibbly legs make him less manouverable than an asthmatic sloth, and his wobbly arms mean that swinging anything bigger than a toothpick is a real struggle for our intrepid hero. Even more unfortunate for our dashing dispatcher of ne'er do wells, the villainous villains he encounters have some deviously diabolical tricks up their muscular sleeves.

Every one of these no good rascals comes equipped with an invisible record player, which they stand upon. What this means for mighty Jellyman is that all these cads he encounters can swivel on the spot... without moving their feet! The KNAVES! The SCOUNDRELS! The UTTER CHEEK! Our poor hero must face large, brutish enemies, who hide behind mighty shields, have vast qauntities of health, and who only give miniscule openings in their defence. These dastardly fiends laugh at our delicious Jelly hero, for they know that further down the corridor, two more of their identical brethren lie in wait - and our gruff protagonist must face them all, lest he be overwhelmed! Oh the horror...

Although, it's not all bad news for our gelatinous champion.
On his quest, he is accompanied by his best pal, Jam, the friendly invisible cameraman! Jam eagerly follows Jelly Goat Gruff on his delectable adventures. Unfortunately, Jam gets a little giddy whenever his pal Jellyman charges into battle, and can't keep a firm grip on his camera.
Also accompanying our damn tasty chum is Karlo...Kaslo?...Carlos? Whatever. Our ABSOLUTELY memorable pal Karlos freed the magnificent Jellygruff from his horrible jelly prison, where our hero was placed after attempting a coup against the Ice Cream king, to supplant him from the delicious dessert throne. Mage-o Kazooie brings Gruff McJellyjelly to Keystone to fight the nasty demons, because only he, with his superior reflexes, nimble footwork, and masterful weapon-handling, can save the day from EVIL!

Our gastronomical hero also gains assistance from an amiable demon blacksmith!
"I can inscribe your weapons with runes to make them worthy of Gods!", he proudly claims.
Lo and behold!, Jellyman was overjoyed to find that his now godly weapon turned a monster that previously took 12 hits to kill, into a monster that now takes a measly 11 hits to vanquish.

Oh yeah, there's also this woman, Yetka or something. She definitely wasn't as memorable as Kazoozle, the COMPLETELY memorable shop dude. Also, there was some bad dude who's name began with M. But who cares, he was just a butthole.


Dare you join the mighty Jellyman on his quest?

Dare you battle these fearsome record player equipped demons?

Dare you slog through dozens and dozens of said demons, over and over again?

Dare you wrestle with the dreadful beast known as the inventory?

Dare you attempt to make sense of cryptic item descriptions that tell you nothing of
an item's purpose?

Dare you listen to grim and chilling audio logs?

Dare you battle visually identical, yet stastically superior versions of foes you have
already fought?

Dare you behold Jam's shaky camera-work, while keeping your dinner intact?

Dare you become... THE JELLYGRUFF?

Obviously I enjoy The Binding of Issac, as evidenced by my hours, but I would like to express my relationship with Issac as I feel it is one of the single greatest pieces of media I've ever consumed. 

Issac is not a game. Issac is a way of life. The strangle-hold this game has on my life is unparalleled. It is not about me being unable to put down Issac, I can very well be in the mood or not in the mood for Issac, its about when I am Invested in Issac. I wake up with my goals in mind clear as day and I crave the dopamine rush I receive from calculating the perfect play. Blasting through rooms with ease knowing the run will end soon and I will have to restart from ground zero yet again. The grind is simple to understand, hard to execute. The game also shows logic constantly, giving the player items early in the run to test the player's thinking. A flight book could be given to the player with zero value in sight, only to be validated 20 minutes later in the run. The Binding of Issac talks to you. It communicates with you. Are you listening?

The game of Issac is simple, and someone new can get countless hours discovering all of the enemies, items, synergies, secrets, rules, etc. As that player grows, the rules of Issac can bend and contort to new unknown levels. I have 721+ hours in Issac (Steam time + Flash Issac days) and every time I play Issac I learn something new. I have also had the pleasure of sharing Issac with my girlfriend. I generally don't talk about Issac, probably due to the game being so weird, but I introduced Issac to my girlfriend and she also fell in love. That's when I understood that Issac is a universal joy. A simple game that can be enjoyed and loved by the young and old. Much like a fine wine, Issac matures as time passes. 

If I were on a desert island, and I could only bring one game, I would bring Issac. It's not even my favourite game, damn near close, however. It's simply because Issac is Infinite. I adore you Issac and Edmund McMillen and all of the developers for Issac. Long live the greatest piece of media that ever existed.

Насчёт этой игры у меня много впечатлений, вспоминая старый Айзек тот который был на Flash player(Дай бог ему память), или даже новый вышедший ремейк Айзека (The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, 4 ноября в 2014 году созданный Эдмунд Макмилленом оправдывает своё ожидание) 
Очень интересный сюжет, классная музыка и персонажи которые имеют свою механику, особенно Альт персонажи, это самое то что бы почувствовать от игры вызов, но и по игре самой много что можно сказать, огромное разнообразие врагов, боссов, и концовки которые полностью рассказывающие сюжет дают игре настоящий потенциал, за моё проведенное время в игре я сразу готов сказать, что игра сделана отлично. 
Если вам вдруг нравится жанр Rogue-Like и вы любите исследовать новые этажи в которых с каждый разом становятся все сложнее враги, то вам сюда!

Here are some of pros and cons;

+++Pros+++:
 
-Best replayability you'll ever find in a video game.
-Some synergies are really fun to play.
-Workshop modding makes it easier to modify sounds/musics or even add characters/floors/utilities like item descriptions.
-New difficulty added with the tainted version of characters.
-New online feature (currently in beta). 

---Cons---: 

-Require a lot of knowledge to not ruin your run with bad synergies (or use Platinumgod / description mod).
-Can be hard at first for beginners.
-Maybe too many endings (i mean to properly understand the lore).
-Achieving dead god will take you a huge amount of time if you're a new (but completionist) player.

Y'all........ I love this game. I know a lot of people are playing with mods but I decided not to (YET) and absolutely LOVEEE this game. At first I thought it was going to be simple, boring and the same thing over and over but this got me HOOKED. The story had me laughing from the beginning. SPOILER ALERT: The goal is to essentially kill your mom to get out of a basement she and you are in. Mom is the big boss but you will come across so many different kinds of monsters. The more you play, the more items you unlock and the more challenging it is. I did think it was a bit boring first but then I found the actual CHALLENGES like, "Have A Heart, April Fools, Pitch Black" and so many more... oof. I been on it. I've played a bit over 200 hours now and try to make more time to play during the week. This is in my top 3 go-to games and always is my first choice. If you're still thinking of buying or not buying...BUY THE GAME!! :)
